How much more pounds does he get out of wraps versus sleeves.", "answer": "The sleeves add 30 pounds to his 600 pound squat so they add 30/600 = <<30/600=0.05>>0.05 to his lift\nThe wraps add 25% to his 600-pound squat so they add 0.25*600= <<25*.01*600=150>>150 pounds to his lift\nThe wraps add 150 pounds to his lift and the sleeves add 30 pounds so the difference is 150-30 = <<150-30=120>>120 pounds\n#### 120"}

{"question": "Janice adds 2 tablespoons of koolaid power and 16 tablespoons of water to a jug. She leaves it out long enough for 4 tablespoons of water to evaporate. Then she quadruples the amount of water in the jug. What percentage of the liquid in the jug is koolaid powder?", "answer": "First find how many tablespoons of water are left after the evaporation: 16 tbs - 4 tbs = <<16-4=12>>12 tbs\nThen multiply this number by 4 to find how much water is in the jug after Janice refills it: 12 tbs * 4 = <<12*4=48>>48 tbs\nNow add the 2 tablespoons of koolaid powder to find the total volume of the liquid in the jug: 48 tbs + 2 tbs = <<48+2=50>>50 tbs\nNow divide the volume of the koolaid powder by the total volume and multiply by 100% to find the percentage of the liquid that's koolaid: 2 tbs / 50 tbs * 100% = 4%\n#### 4"}

{"question": "A printing press is printing brochures. The press prints 20 single-page spreads, and twice as many double-page spreads. For each 4 pages printed for the spreads, the press prints a block of 4 ads, each of which take up a quarter of a page. The brochures can be arranged in any order as long as they are made up of 5 pages each. How many brochures is the printing press creating?", "answer": "There are a total of 20 single-page spreads * 2 = <<20*2=40>>40 double-page spreads.\nAs these are made up of 2 pages each, there are 40 double-page spreads * 2 pages = <<40*2=80>>80 pages in the double-page spreads.\nIn total, there are 20 single-pages + 80 double-pages = <<20+80=100>>100 pages in the spreads.\nA block of ads is printed every 4 pages, so there will be 100 pages / 4 pages/block = <<100/4=25>>25 blocks of ads.\nThis is a total of 25 blocks * 4 ads = <<25*4=100>>100 ads.\nAs each ad takes up a quarter of a page, this must create an additional 100 ads * 0.25 = <<100*0.25=25>>25 pages.\nTherefore, the press has printed 100 pages from the spreads + 25 pages of ads = <<100+25=125>>125 pages.\nSince brochures are made up of 5 pages each, this creates a total of 125 pages / 5 = <<125/5=25>>25 brochures.\n#### 25"}

How many more pairs of underwear can he add to the wash and not break the rule?", "answer": "He is washing 10 ounces of shirts because 2 x 5 = <<2*5=10>>10\nHe is washing 6 ounces of socks because 3 x 2 = <<3*2=6>>6\nHe is already washing 34 ounces of clothes because 10 + 10 + 8 + 6 = <<10+10+8+6=34>>34\nHe can wash 16 more ounces of clothes because 50 - 34 = <<50-34=16>>16\nHe can wash 4 pairs of underwear because 16 / 4 = <<16/4=4>>4\n#### 4"}

{"question": "Hayden has a tank with a small hole in the bottom. The tank starts with 40 gallons of water. It loses 2 gallons of water per hour. Hayden does not add any water for the first two hours. He adds 1 gallon of water to the tank in hour three. He adds three gallons of water to the tank in the fourth hour. How much water is left in the tank at the end of the fourth hour?", "answer": "The tank loses 2 gallons of water per hour. In the first two hours, the tank loses 2 * 2 = <<2*2=4>>4 gallons of water.\nIn the third hour, Hayden adds 1 gallon of water to the tank, so the tank loses 2 - 1 = <<2-1=1>>1 gallon of water.\nIn the fourth hour, Hayden adds 3 gallons of water to the tank, so the tank loses 2 - 3 = <<2-3=-1>>-1 gallon of water.\nThe tank starts with 40 gallons of water, and loses a total of 4 + 1 - 1 = <<4+1-1=4>>4 gallons of water.\nThere is 40 - 4 = <<40-4=36>>36 gallons of water left in the tank at the end of the fourth hour.\n#### 36"}

A while later, an animal rescue contacted them, and the zoo took in three endangered rhinos. Then one of their lionesses gave birth to cubs, and they opened a meerkat exhibit with twice as many meerkats as they had gained lion cubs. The zoo then had 90 animals in all. How many lion cubs were born at the zoo?", "answer": "Let C be the number of lion cubs.\nThere are twice as many meerkats in the new exhibit, so there are 2C meerkats.\nThe zoo sent 4 gorillas away, so there were 68 - 6 = <<68-6=62>>62 animals left.\nThey adopted a hippopotamus, so there were 62 + 1 = <<62+1=63>>63 animals.\nThey took in 3 rhinos, so there were 63 + 3 = <<63+3=66>>66 animals.\nThus, there were 90 - 66 = <<90-66=24>>24 new lion cubs and meerkats.\nTherefore, there were C + 2C = 3C = 24 new lion cubs as meerkats as there were lion cubs.\nThus, there were C = 24 / 3 = <<24/3=8>>8 lion cubs.\n#### 8"}

If the man must drive to work 20 days each month, what is the difference between the total monthly costs of these two apartments after factoring in utility and driving-related costs (to the nearest whole dollar)?", "answer": "The mileage cost for the first apartment will be 31*20*0.58 = $<<31*20*0.58=359.60>>359.60\nThis makes the total monthly cost of the first apartment 359.60 + 800 + 260 = $<<359.60+800+260=1419.60>>1419.60\nSimilarly, the mileage cost for the second apartment will be 21*20*0.58 = $<<21*20*0.58=243.60>>243.60\nThus, the total monthly cost of the second apartment is 243.60 + 900 + 200 = <<243.60+900+200=1343.60>>1343.60\nTherefore, the difference in total monthly costs is 1419.60 - 1343.60 = $<<1419.60-1343.60=76>>76\n#### 76"}

How much longer must the cell phone be charged to reach 100% charge?", "answer": "The cell phone was initially empty, so it needs to be charged for 100% - 0% = 100% of the time\nIt has already been charged for 25% of the time, so it needs to be charged for 100% - 25% = <<100%-25%=75%>>75% of the time\nIt has been charged for 45 minutes, so it needs to be charged for 75% of 45 minutes = 45 * 75% = <<45*.75=33.75>>33.75 minutes\n#### 33.75"}

Finally, on Friday it rained for half the day and she managed to pull up 10 fewer weeds than she did on Thursday. In total, how many weeds did she pull up?", "answer": "On Wednesday she pulled 25*3=<<25*3=75>>75 weeds\nOn Thursday she pulled 75*1/5=<<75*1/5=15>>15 weeds\nOn Friday she pulled 15-10=<<15-10=5>>5 weeds\nIn total she pulled 25+75+15+5= <<25+75+15+5=120>>120 weeds\n#### 120"}
{"question": "Martin spends 2 hours waiting in traffic, then four times that long trying to get off the freeway. How much time does he waste total?", "answer": "First find the total amount of time he spends trying to get off the freeway: 2 hours * 4 = <<2*4=8>>8 hours\nThen add the time he spends waiting in traffic to find the total time: 8 hours + 2 hours = <<8+2=10>>10 hours\n#### 10"}

{"question": "Julio receives a $1 commission for every customer that buys in Edgars Fashion Store. The store sells to 35 customers in the first week, twice as many in the second week, and triple as many as the first week in the third week. If he receives a salary of $500 for the 3 weeks and a bonus of $50, how much in total does he earn for the 3 weeks?", "answer": "The number of customers who buy in the second week is 35 customers * 2 = <<35*2=70>>70 customers.\nThe number of customers who buy in the third week is 35 customers * 3 = <<35*3=105>>105 customers.\nThe total number of customers who bought during the 3 weeks is 35 customers + 70 customers + 105 customers = <<35+70+105=210>>210 customers\nThe amount of money he earns in commission is 210 customers * $1 per customer = $<<210*1=210>>210.\nThe total income he earns for the 3 weeks is $210 + $500 + $50 = $<<210+500+50=760>>760.\n#### 760"}

How much money did Anna have left?", "answer": "Anna bought 3 packs of chewing gum that were $1 each for a total of 3*1=$<<3*1=3>>3\nAnna bought 5 chocolate bars that were $1 each for a total of 5*1=$<<5=5>>5\nAnna bought 2 large candy canes that were $0.50 each for a total of 2*0.50=$<<2*0.50=1>>1\nIn total Anna spent 3+5+1=$<<3+5+1=9>>9\nHer mom gave her $10 to spend and she spent $9 so she has 10-9=$<<10-9=1>>1 left\n#### 1"}

If Ana will be 15 in 3 years, how old is Sarah?", "answer": "First find how old Ana is right now: 15 years - 3 years = <<15-3=12>>12 years\nThen find how old Billy is: 12 years / 2 = <<12/2=6>>6 years\nThen find how old Mark is: 6 years + 4 years = <<6+4=10>>10 years\nThen find how old Sarah is: 3 * 10 years - 4 years = <<3*10-4=26>>26 years\n#### 26"}
{"question": "Jake is watching a new show, and is worried about how much time he has spent watching it. He spent half the day on Monday watching his show, 4 hours on Tuesday watching his show, a quarter of the day on Wednesday watching his show, and he spent half as much time watching the show on Thursday as he had done in total throughout the previous few days. On Friday, he finally finished watching it. If the entire show is 52 hours long, how many hours did Jake watch on Friday?", "answer": "On Monday, Jake watched 24 hours / 2 = <<24/2=12>>12 hours.\nOn Wednesday, he watched 24 hours / 4 = <<24/4=6>>6 hours.\nHe watched 12 Monday hours + 4 Tuesday hours + 6 Wednesday hours = <<12+4+6=22>>22 hours in the first 3 days.\nTo watch half of this on Thursday, he would have to have watched 22 hours / 2 = <<22/2=11>>11 hours.\nSo, he has watched 12 Monday hours + 4 Tuesday hours + 6 Wednesday hours + 11 Thursday hours = <<12+4+6+11=33>>33 hours.\nTo finish the show on Friday, he must have therefore watched 52 total hours \u2013 33 hours watched = <<52-33=19>>19 hours on Friday.\n#### 19"}

If the fan works for 10 minutes each day, calculate the amount of airflow it will create in one week.", "answer": "The fan works for 10 minutes per day. There are 60 seconds in a minute, and 60 minutes in an hour, so the fan creates 10*60*60 = <<10*60*60=36000>>36000 liters per hour.\nThe fan works for 0.0034722222 hours per day, so the fan creates 36000*0.0034722222 = <<36000*0.0034722222=124.3055556>>124.3055556 liters per day.\nThe fan works for 7 days per week, so the fan creates 7*124.3055556 = <<7*124.3055556=871.1438892>>871.1438892 liters per week.\n#### 871.1438892"}

{"question": "Jenny is planning her catering budget for her wedding. She's going to have 80 guests. 3 times as many guests want steak as chicken. If each steak entree costs $25 and each chicken entree costs $18, how much is the total catering budget?", "answer": "Let s be the number of guests who want steak and c be the number who want chicken. We know that s + c = 80 and s = 3c.\nSubstituting the second equation into the first equation, we get 3c + c = 80\nCombining like terms, we get 4c = 80\nDividing both sides of the equation by 4, we get c = 20\nSubstituting this value back into s = 3c, we get s = 3 * 20 = <<3*20=60>>60\nTherefore, the total cost of the steaks is 60 * $25 = $<<60*25=1500>>1500\nThe total cost of the chickens is 20 * $18 = $<<20*18=360>>360\nThe total catering budget is $1500 + $360 = $<<1500+360=1860>>1860\n#### 1860"}

How many more jeans are there than scarves?", "answer": "The sum of black and white shirts is 63 + 42 = <<63+42=105>>105.\nThe store has 105 x 2/3 = <<105*2/3=70>>70 jeans.\nThe sum of ties and belts is 34 + 40 = <<34+40=74>>74.\nThere are 74/2 = <<74/2=37>>37 scarfs in the store.\nThere are 70 - 37 = <<70-37=33>>33 more jeans than scarfs.\n#### 33"}
{"question": "Mary and Ann are going sledding. Mary slides down a hill that's 630 feet long at a speed of 90 feet/minute. Ann slides down a hill that's 800 feet long at a rate of 40 feet/minute. How much longer does Ann's trip take than Mary?", "answer": "First find the total time Mary's trip takes: 630 feet / 90 feet/minute = <<630/90=7>>7 minutes\nThen find the total time Ann's trip takes: 800 feet / 40 feet/minute = <<800/40=20>>20 minutes\nThen subtract Mary's time from Ann's time to find the difference: 20 minutes - 7 minutes = <<20-7=13>>13 minutes\n#### 13"}
{"question": "There are 28 students in a classroom. Half of them have 5 notebooks each and the other half have 3 notebooks each. How many notebooks in total are in the classroom?", "answer": "Half of the class consists of 28 students / 2 = <<28/2=14>>14 students.\nOne half of the students have 14 students * 3 notebooks/student = <<14*3=42>>42 notebooks.\nThe other half have 14 students * 5 notebooks/student = <<14*5=70>>70 notebooks.\nThere are 42 notebooks + 70 notebooks = <<42+70=112>>112 notebooks in total in the classroom.\n#### 112"}
{"question": "Erica is telling her grandson about the animals she saw during her recent safari in Kenya's Maasai Mara. On Saturday, she saw 3 lions and 2 elephants. She spotted 2 buffaloes and 5 leopards on Sunday, and 5 rhinos and 3 warthogs on Monday. What is the total number of animals that Erica saw?", "answer": "On Saturday Erica saw 3 + 2 = <<3+2=5>>5 animals\nOn Sunday she spotted 2 + 5 = <<2+5=7>>7 animals\nOn Monday, the last day of her safari, she saw 5 + 3 = <<5+3=8>>8 animals\nAdding up all the animals Erica saw gives a total of 5 + 7 + 8 = <<5+7+8=20>>20 animals\n#### 20"}
{"question": "Caroline has 40 pairs of socks. She loses 4 pairs of socks at the laundromat. Of the remaining pairs of socks, she donates two-thirds to the thrift store. Then she purchases 10 new pairs of socks, and she receives 3 new pairs of socks as a gift from her dad. How many pairs of socks does Caroline have in total?", "answer": "If Caroline had 40 pairs of socks and loses 4, she has 40 - 4 = <<40-4=36>>36 pairs of socks\nOf the remaining pairs of socks, she donates 2/3*36 = <<2/3*36=24>>24 pairs of socks to the thrift store\nAfter donating some socks, she is left with 36 - 24 = <<36-24=12>>12 pairs of socks\nAfter getting new socks, she has 12 + 10 + 3 = <<12+10+3=25>>25 pairs of socks\n#### 25"}

{"question": "Abel leaves for a vacation destination 1000 miles away driving 50 miles per hour.  An hour later Alice leaves from the same point for the same destination, traveling 40 miles per hour. How much earlier does Abel reach the destination in minutes??", "answer": "If Abel needs to travel 1000 miles going 50 miles per hour, this means it will take him 1000/50=<<1000/50=20>>20 hours to get there.\nIf Alice needs to travel 1000 miles going 40 miles per hour, this means it will take her 1000/40=<<1000/40=25>>25 hours to get there.\nSince there are 60 minutes in an hour, this means it will take Abel 20*60= <<20*60=1200>>1200 minutes to arrive.\nSimilarly, this means it will take Alice 25*60= <<25*60=1500>>1500 minutes to arrive.\nThis means Abel arrives 1500-1200= <<1500-1200=300>>300 minutes before Alice if they both leave simultaneously.\nHowever, since Abel had a head start of 1 hour, which is 60 minutes, this means Abel arrives 300 + 60 = <<300+60=360>>360 minutes ahead of Alice\n#### 360"}

How many bars does this represent?", "answer": "2 kg = 2 * 1000 = <<2*1000=2000>>2000 g\n1 box = <<2000=2000>>2000 g\n1 bar = 125 g\n2000/125 = <<2000/125=16>>16 bars\nThe shopkeeper has just received 16 bars.\n#### 16"}
{"question": "Tom decides to lease a car.  He drives 50 miles on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday, and Sunday for the rest of the days he drives 100 miles.  He has to pay $.1 per mile he drives.  He also has to pay a weekly fee of $100.  How much does he have to pay in a year.", "answer": "He does the long drive 7-4=<<7-4=3>>3 days a week\nSo he does the short drive 4*50=<<4*50=200>>200 miles\nHe does the long drive 100*3=<<100*3=300>>300 miles\nSo he drives a total of 300+200=<<300+200=500>>500 miles a week\nThat means he pays 500*.1=$<<500*.1=50>>50 just for the mileage\nSo he pays 100+50=$<<100+50=150>>150 per week\nSo he pays 150*52=$<<150*52=7800>>7800 a year\n#### 7800"}

What percentage of all the plants in her two gardens are tomato plants?", "answer": "In the first garden, she has 20 plants and 10% are tomato plants.\nIn the second garden, she has 15 plants and 1/3 of these plants are tomato plants.\nTotal tomato plants are 20(0.10) + 15(1/3) = <<20*0.10+15/3=2.5+5=7.5>>7.5 plants.\nTotal plants are 20 + 15 = <<20+15=35>>35 plants.\nThe percentage of all the plants in her two gardens are 7.5/35 x 100% = <<7.5/35*100=21.4%>>21.4%.\n#### 21.4%"}

In one day, the candy store makes 100 lollipops and 5 hard candies. They do not use food colouring in anything else. The store has used 600ml of food colouring by the end of the day. How much food colouring, in millilitres, does each hard candy need?", "answer": "In total, the lollipops needed 100 lollipops * 5ml of food colouring per lollipop = <<100*5=500>>500ml of food colouring.\nThis means that the hard candies needed 600ml total food colouring used \u2013 500 ml food colouring used for lollipops = 100ml of food colouring.\nAs there were 5 hard candies, this means that each hard candy needed 100ml of food colouring needed for hard candies / 5 hard candies = <<100/5=20>>20 ml of food colouring.\n#### 20"}

The building has twenty flights of stairs to the top floor, and Ned can run up one flight of stairs in eleven seconds. The time bomb has 72 seconds left on the timer, and Ned has spent 165 seconds running up the stairs. How many seconds will Ned have to diffuse the bomb when he reaches it?", "answer": "Ned has gone up 165 / 11 = <<165/11=15>>15 flights of stairs.\nThus, he has 20 - 15 = <<20-15=5>>5 flights of stairs left to run up.\nHe will spend 5 * 11 = <<5*11=55>>55 seconds running up the remaining stairs to the bomb.\nTherefore, he will have 72 - 55 = <<72-55=17>>17 seconds to defuse the bomb.\n#### 17"}

{"question": "Jack goes up three flights of stairs, then down six flights of stairs. If each flight of stairs has 12 steps that each each 8 inches high, how many feet further down is Jack than when he started?", "answer": "First find how many inches are in each flight of stairs: 12 steps * 8 inches/step = <<12*8=96>>96 inches\nThen find the net number of flights of stairs Jack went down: 6 flights - 3 flights = <<6-3=3>>3 flights\nThen multiply that number by the number of inches per flight to find how many inches further down he is: 96 inches/flight * 3 flights = <<96*3=288>>288 inches\nThen divide that number by 12 to find the number of feet down he is: 288 inches / 12 inches/foot = 24 feet\n#### 24"}

How many hours, in total, did Ayen jog this week?", "answer": "Ayen jogged for a total of 30 x 3 = <<30*3=90>>90 minutes on Monday, Wednesday, and Thursday.\nShe jogged for 30 + 5 = <<30+5=35>>35 minutes on Tuesday.\nShe also jogged for 30 + 25 = <<30+25=55>>55 minutes on Friday.\nSo, Ayen jogged for a total of 90 + 35 + 55 = <<90+35+55=180>>180 minutes.\nIn hours, this is equal to 180 minutes / 60 minutes/hour = <<180/60=3>>3 hours.\n#### 3"}

How many $20 bills do they have in their fund?", "answer": "If n is the number of $20 bills then 2n is the number of $10 bills.\nSo the equation will be $10(2n) + $20n = $120.\nBy combining like terms, the equation becomes 40n = 120.\nSo, the value of n which represents the number of $20 bills is 120/40 = <<120/40=3>>3.\n#### 3"}

{"question": "A small, old, wooden bridge can hold up to 100 kilograms at once. Mike, Megan, and Kelly are three children who decided to cross the bridge at the same time. Kelly weighs 34 kilograms, which is 15% less than Megan. Mike weighs 5 kilograms more than Megan. How much too much do the three children weigh together to cross the bridge?", "answer": "If Kelly weighs 15% less than Megan, this means Kelly weighs 100% - 15% = 85% of Megan's weight.\n85% is 0.85, so Megan weighs 34 / 0.85 = <<34/0.85=40>>40 kilograms.\nMike weighs 5 kilograms more than Megan, which means he weighs 40 + 5 = <<5+40=45>>45 kilograms.\nIn total all three kids weigh 34 + 40 + 45 = <<34+40+45=119>>119 kilograms.\nThat means to cross the bridge safely, they weigh 119 - 100 = <<119-100=19>>19 kilograms too much.\n#### 19"}

If he has 20 bags of jerky already made, how many days will it be before he can fulfill the customer\u2019s order?", "answer": "Wallace already has 20 bags of jerky, so he needs to make 60 - 20 = <<60-20=40>>40 bags more.\nHe can make 10 bags per batch, so he needs 40 / 10 = <<40/10=4>>4 batches.\nIt takes all night to make one batch, so he needs 4 * 1 = 4 days to fulfill the customer\u2019s order.\n#### 4"}

{"question": "A woman is trying to decide whether it will be quicker to take an airplane or drive herself to a job interview. If she drives herself, the trip will take her 3 hours and 15 minutes.  If she takes an airplane, she will first need to drive 10 minutes to the airport, and then wait 20 minutes to board the plane.  After that, she will be on the airplane for one-third of the time it would have taken her to drive herself before landing in the destination city. Finally, it will take her an additional 10 minutes to get off the airplane and arrive at her interview site after the plane lands.  Given this information, how many minutes faster is it for her to take the airplane?", "answer": "First, we must convert the driving time of 3 hours and 15 minutes to minutes. 3 hours is 3*60=<<3*60=180>>180 minutes.\nThus, driving takes a total of 180+15=<<180+15=195>>195 minutes.\nNext, the woman will be on the airplane for one-third of 195 minutes, or 195/3 = <<195/3=65>>65 minutes.\nThus, in total, the airplane trip will take the woman 10+20+65+10 = <<10+20+65+10=105>>105 minutes.\nTherefore, the airplane trip is 195-105 = <<195-105=90>>90 minutes faster than driving herself to the interview.\n#### 90"}

If the garden has 400 bugs to start, and Bill sprays once and introduces 12 spiders, how many bugs are left?", "answer": "First find the total number of bugs killed by the spiders: 12 spiders * 7 bugs/spider = <<12*7=84>>84 bugs\nThen find the total bug population after spraying: 80% * 400 bugs = <<80*.01*400=320>>320 bugs\nThen subtract the number of bugs killed by the spiders from the number of bugs left after spraying to find final number of bugs: 320 bugs - 84 bugs = <<320-84=236>>236 bugs\n#### 236"}

She grabs a pound of tomatoes and 2 pounds of zucchini.  After that, she grabs 1 1/2 pounds of chicken breasts and treats herself to 8 ounces of fresh raspberries and 8 ounces of fresh blueberries.  How many pounds of food does she buy?", "answer": "She buys 8 ounces of brie, which is <<8/16=.5>>.5 of a pound.\nShe buys 1 pound of bread.\nShe buys 1 pound of tomatoes.\nShe buys 2 pounds of zucchini.\nShe buys 1.5 pounds of chicken breasts.\nShe buys 8 ounces of raspberries, which is <<8/16=.5>>.5 of a pound.\nShe buys 8 ounces of blueberries, which is <<8/16=.5>>.5 of a pound.\nShe buys a total of 4.5 + 1 + 1 + 2 + 1.5 + .5 + .5 = <<4.5+1+1+2+1.5+.5+.5=11>>11 pounds of food.\n#### 11"}
{"question": "Hortense loves daisies and sunflowers.  She planted 25 daisy seeds and 25 sunflower seeds in her flower bed.  If 60% of the daisy seeds germinate, and 80% of the sunflower seeds germinate, and 80% of the resulting plants produce flowers, how many plants will she grow that produce flowers?", "answer": "Of the 25 daisy seeds, 60% will germinate, for a total of 60/100*25=<<60/100*25=15>>15 plants.\nOf the 25 sunflower seeds, 80% will germinate, for a total of 80/100*25=<<80/100*25=20>>20 plants.\nIn total, she will have grown 15+20=<<15+20=35>>35 plants.\nIf 80% of the plants developed flowers, then she will have grown (80/100)*35=<<(80/100)*35=28>>28 plants that produce flowers.\n#### 28"}
{"question": "Marcy is the lunch monitor in an elementary school cafeteria. She gives 5 time-outs for running, 1 less than five times that number of time-outs for throwing food, and 1/3 the number of food-throwing time-outs for swearing. If each time-out is 5 minutes, how much time do the students spend in time-out total?", "answer": "First multiply the number of running time-outs by 5: 5 time-outs * 5 = <<5*5=25>>25 time-outs\nThen subtract 1 from that number to get the number of food-throwing time-outs: 25 time-outs - 1 = <<25-1=24>>24 time-outs\nThen divide that number by 3 to find the number of swearing time-outs: 24 time-outs / 3 = <<24/3=8>>8 time-outs\nThen add the number of each kind of time-out to find the total number: 5 time-outs + 24 time-outs + 8 time-outs = <<5+24+8=37>>37 time-outs\nThen multiply that number by the length of each time-out to find the total time the students spend in time-out: 37 time-outs * 5 minutes/time-out = <<37*5=185>>185 minutes\n#### 185"}
{"question": "Lauryn owns a computer company that employs men and women in different positions in the company. How many men does he employ if there are 20 fewer men than women and 180 people working for Lauryn?", "answer": "Let's say the number of men working at the company is x.\nSince there are 180 people, and the number of men is 20 fewer than the number of women, then x+x+20 = 180\nThe total number of employees in the company is 2x+20 = 180.\nAfter removing 20 from both sides of the equation, we get 2x = 180 -20 = 160\nThe number of men is x = 160/2 = <<160/2=80>>80.\n#### 80"}
{"question": "A soccer team had 24 players prepared for a soccer game. The first half saw 11 players start the game with 2 substitutions made. In the second half, the team made twice as many substitutions as it made in the first half. How many players on the team did not play that day?", "answer": "With 2 substitutions, 11+2 = <<11+2=13>>13 players from the team played the game in the first half.\nIn the second half, the team made twice the number of substitutions it made in the first half, a total of 2*2 = <<2*2=4>>4 substitutions.\nWith 4 substitutions, 13+4 = <<13+4=17>>17 players played the game.\nFrom the total number of players prepared for the soccer game, 24-17 = <<24-17=7>>7 players did not play the game.\n#### 7"}
{"question": "Jerry has a bunch of half-empty soda cans on his desk. He needs to drain all of them and put them in the recycling bin. He can carry four cans at once, and it takes him 30 seconds to drain those 4 cans. It takes him ten seconds each way to walk to the sink and recycling bin and then back to his desk. If there are 28 cans on Jerry's desk, how long does it take him to throw all of them away?", "answer": "Jerry has to walk to the sink/recycling bin 28 cans / 4 cans per walk = <<28/4=7>>7 walks\nThe round trip takes 10 seconds per way * 2 ways = <<10*2=20>>20 seconds per walk\nIt takes 30 seconds per walk + 20 seconds per walk = <<30+20=50>>50 seconds per walk\nCounting all the walks, it will take Jerry 50 seconds per walk * 7 walks = <<50*7=350>>350 seconds\n#### 350"}

If she tans 30 minutes a day, two days a week for the first two weeks of the month, how many minutes can she tan in the last two weeks of the month?", "answer": "First find how many minutes Jenna tans each of the first two weeks: 30 minutes/day * 2 days/week = <<30*2=60>>60 minutes/week\nThen find how many weeks are in the month: 4 weeks/month - 2 weeks = <<4-2=2>>2 weeks\nThen find how many minutes Jenna tans in the last two weeks: 60 minutes/week * 2 weeks = <<60*2=120>>120 minutes\nThen subtract the minutes Jenna has already tanned from the total number of minutes she can spend tanning to find how many more minutes she can tan: 200 minutes - 120 minutes = <<200-120=80>>80 minutes\n#### 80"}
{"question": "Janet is trying to decide whether to quit her job and start freelancing. She works 40 hours a week at both jobs. She get paid $30/hour at her current job, and would get paid $40/hour as a freelancer. However, she'd have to pay an extra $25 a week in FICA taxes plus $400/month in healthcare premiums. How much more would Janet make per month as a freelancer if there are four weeks in a month?", "answer": "First find the difference in hourly wages: $40/hour - $30/hour = $<<40-30=10>>10/hour\nThen multiply that difference by the number of hours she works in a week to find the weekly difference: $10/hour * 40 hours/week = $<<10*40=400>>400/week\nThen multiply that amount by the number of weeks in a month to find the monthly difference in her earnings: $400/week * 4 weeks/month = $<<400*4=1600>>1600/month\nThen find the total additional amount Janet pays in FICA taxes: $25/week * 4 weeks/month = $<<25*4=100>>100/month\nThen subtract Janet's extra FICA taxes and healthcare premium from the additional money she earns to find the net increase in her pay from freelancing: $1600/month - $400/month - $100/month = $<<1600-400-100=1100>>1100/month\n#### 1100"}

How many more minutes did she watch over the weekend?", "answer": "Maddie watches 8 episodes of a TV show this week. Each episode is about 44 minutes long. So she watches 8*44 = <<8*44=352>>352 minutes of the TV show during the week\nOn Friday, she watches 2*44 = <<2*44=88>>88 minutes of the TV show.\nOn Monday, Thursday, and Friday, Maddie watches 138+21+88 = <<138+21+88=247>>247 minutes of the TV show.\nThus, on the weekend she watches 352-247 = <<352-247=105>>105 minutes of the TV show.\n#### 105"}

How many hours in total have Oliver worked out during these four days?", "answer": "On Tuesday, Oliver worked out for 4 hours - 2 hours = <<4-2=2>>2 hours.\nOn Wednesday he decided to work out twice as much as on Monday, which would be 4 hours * 2 = <<4*2=8>>8 hours.\nOn Thursday, Oliver trained twice as much as on Tuesday, which would be 2 hours * 2 = <<2*2=4>>4 hours.\nIn total Oliver trained for 4 hours + 2 hours + 8 hours + 4 hours = <<4+2+8+4=18>>18 hours.\n#### 18"}

If Ms. Azalea sold a pound of wool at $20, how much profit did she make from the produce of her sheep farm?", "answer": "Since there were 200 sheep, the amount of wool Azalea got after the sheep were sheared is 200*10 = <<200*10=2000>>2000 pounds of wool.\nIf she sold one pound of wool at $20, the total amount of money she made from the sheep farm is 2000*$20 = $<<2000*20=40000>>40000\nHer profit, which is the excess of the money she got after selling the wool over the amount she paid to the sheep shearer, is $40000-$2000 = $<<40000-2000=38000>>38000\n#### 38000"}

But Grimzi, the three-legged Plutonian, leaves only 3 footprints in the soft sands of Pluto for every 6 meters it walks. (Remember you can find the area of a triangle by dividing the area of a square with the same height and length by 2). How many square inches of canvas does she need total?", "answer": "First figure out how much canvas you need for the square sail: 5 inches * 8 inches = <<5*8=40>>40 square inches\nThen figure out how much canvas you need for one of the triangular sails: 3 inches * 4 inches * 0.5 = <<3*4*0.5=6>>6 square inches\nThen double that amount because there are two triangular sails: 6 square inches * 2 = <<6*2=12>>12 square inches\nThen add up the amount of canvas needed for all three sails: 12 square inches + 40 square inches + 6 square inches = <<12+40+6=58>>58 square inches\n#### 58"}

How much money does he save per day compared to what he used to spend?", "answer": "John used to spend $2 x 4 = $<<2*4=8>>8 a day on coffee.\nThe price of coffee is now $2 x 1.5 = $<<2*1.5=3>>3 per coffee.\nJohn buys 2 coffees per day at the new price.  So he spends $3 x 2 = $<<3*2=6>>6 per day.\nJohn saves $8 - $6 = $<<8-6=2>>2 per day.\n#### 2"}

In the remaining seconds in the game, the Fireflies scored 7 three-point baskets while holding the Hornets to only 2 two-point baskets to win the game.  How many more points did the Fireflies score in the game than did the Hornets?", "answer": "Since three-point baskets count as three points each, the Fireflies scored 7 three-pointers x 3 points each = <<7*3=21>>21 points in the final 40 seconds of the game.\nIn that same time period, the hornets scored an additional 2 two-pointers x 2 points each = <<2*2=4>>4 points.\nThus, in the final 40 seconds of the game, the Fireflies outscored the hornets 21-4 to turn a 86-74 deficit into a 95-90 victory.\nTherefore, the Fireflies scored 95-90=<<95-90=5>>5 more points than the hornets in the basketball game.\n#### 5"}

{"question": "Mary is counting the number of minnows in the pond. 40% of the minnows have red bellies, 30% have green bellies and the rest have white bellies. If 20 minnows have red bellies, how many minnows have white bellies?", "answer": "First find the total number of minnows by dividing the number of red minnows by the percentage of red minnows: 20 minnows / .4 = <<20/.4=50>>50 minnows\nThen subtract the percentages of red- and green-bellied minnows to find the percentage of white-bellied minnows: 100% - 40% - 30% = 30%\nThen multiply the total number of minnows by the percentage of white-bellied minnows to find the number of white-bellied minnows: 50 minnows * 30% = <<50*30*.01=15>>15 minnows\n#### 15"}

{"question": "Ellie went to visit a circus with Sarah and they both got lost in the house of mirrors. They have to travel through the house of mirrors a few times before they finally get out and when they leave, they discuss how many times they've seen their own reflections. Sarah says that every time they were in the room with tall mirrors, she saw her reflection 10 times and every time they were in the room with wide mirrors, she saw her reflection 5 times. Ellie says that every time they were in the room with tall mirrors, she saw her reflection 6 times and every time they were in the room with wide mirrors she saw her reflection 3 times. They both passed through the room with tall mirrors 3 times each and they both passed through the room with wide mirrors 5 times each. In total, how many times did Sarah and Ellie see their reflections?", "answer": "In the rooms with tall mirrors, Sarah saw her reflection a total of 10 reflections * 3 passes = <<10*3=30>>30 times.\nIn the rooms with wide mirrors, Sarah saw her reflection a total of 5 reflections * 5 passes = <<5*5=25>>25 reflections.\nSo Sarah saw her reflection a total of 30 + 25 = <<30+25=55>>55 times.\nIn the rooms with tall mirrors, Ellie saw her reflection a total of 6 reflections * 3 passes = <<6*3=18>>18 times.\nIn the rooms with wide mirrors, Ellie saw her reflection a total of 3 reflections * 5 passes = <<3*5=15>>15 times.\nSo Ellie saw her reflection a total of 18 + 15 = <<18+15=33>>33 times.\nTherefore, Sarah and Ellie saw their reflections a total of 55 + 33 = <<55+33=88>>88 times.\n#### 88"}

If all the other neighbors took the correct amount of cookies, how many cookies did Sarah take?", "answer": "Sarah and the final neighbor took the wrong amount, which means that 15 neighbors - 1 Sarah - 1 final neighbor = 13 neighbors took the right amount.\nThis is a total of 13 neighbors * 10 cookies = <<13*10=130>>130 correct neighbors.\nSo out of 150 cookies, 130 were taken by the correct neighbors, which means that 150 - 130 = <<150-130=20>>20 cookies were taken incorrectly.\nSince there were only 8 cookies left, then Sarah and the final neighbor took 20 incorrect cookies = 8 + 12 = 20.\nSo Sarah took 12 incorrect cookies = <<12=12>>12 cookies.\n#### 12"}

{"question": "If a basket is capable of holding 40 fruit altogether, and there are 3 times as many apples as oranges, how many oranges are there?", "answer": "Let's say the number of apples is 3 times the number of oranges, which is 3*x=3x.\nIf the total number of fruit the basket is holding is 40, then the total number of apples and oranges is 3x+x=40.\nThe sum of all the fruit therefore totals to 4x=40\nThe number of oranges in the basket is x=40/4.\nIf there are three times as many apples as oranges, and the number of oranges is x, then the number of apples is 3*x.\nThe total number of fruit in the basket is 3x+x=40\n4x=40\nx=<<10=10>>10.\nThe number of oranges in the basket is x=10.\n#### 10"}

{"question": "Eden's mom is twice as old as Eden, who is twice as old as Devin. If Devin is 12 years old, what's the average age of the three?", "answer": "Since Eden is twice as old as Devin, she is 12 * 2 = <<12*2=24>>24 years old.\nEden's mom two times older than Eden, which means she is 24 * 2 = <<24*2=48>>48 years old.\nThe total age of the three is 24 + 48 + 12 = <<24+48+12=84>>84 years.\nThe average age for the three is 84 / 3 = <<84/3=28>>28 years old.\n#### 28"}
{"question": "Carson is a night security guard. He's supposed to patrol the outside of a warehouse that's 600 feet long and 400 feet wide. If Carson is supposed to circle the warehouse 10 times, but gets tired and skips 2 times, how far does he walk in one night?", "answer": "First find the total distance Carson walks along the warehouse's long sides: 600 feet/side * 2 sides = <<600*2=1200>>1200 feet\nThen find the total distance Carson walks along the warehouse's short sides: 400 feet/side * 2 sides = <<400*2=800>>800 feet\nAdd those two amounts to find the total distance Carson walks around the warehouse per trip: 1200 feet + 800 feet = <<1200+800=2000>>2000 feet\nThen find the number of trips Carson actually walks: 10 circles - 2 circles = <<10-2=8>>8 circles\nThen multiply the distance of one circle by the number of circles Carson makes: 2000 feet/circle * 8 circles = <<2000*8=16000>>16000 feet\n#### 16000"}

{"question": "Mark's basketball team scores 25 2 pointers, 8 3 pointers and 10 free throws.  Their opponents score double the 2 pointers but half the 3 pointers and free throws.  What's the total number of points scored by both teams added together?", "answer": "Mark's team scores 25 2 pointers, meaning they scored 25*2= <<25*2=50>>50 points in 2 pointers.\nHis team also scores 6 3 pointers, meaning they scored 8*3= 24 points in 3 pointers\nThey scored 10 free throws, and free throws count as one point so they scored 10*1=<<10*1=10>>10 points in free throws.\nAll together his team scored 50+24+10= <<50+24+10=84>>84 points\nMark's opponents scored double his team's number of 2 pointers, meaning they scored 50*2=<<50*2=100>>100 points in 2 pointers.\nHis opponents scored half his team's number of 3 pointers, meaning they scored 24/2= <<24/2=12>>12 points in 3 pointers.\nThey also scored half Mark's team's points in free throws, meaning they scored 10/2=<<10/2=5>>5 points in free throws.\nAll together Mark's opponents scored 100+12+5=<<100+12+5=117>>117 points\nThe total score for the game is both team's scores added together, so it is 84+117=<<84+117=201>>201 points\n#### 201"}

{"question": "There are two warehouses. The first warehouse has twice as many boxes as the second warehouse. If the first warehouse has 400 boxes, how many boxes are there in both warehouses combined?", "answer": "Let w1 be the number of boxes in the first warehouse and w2 be the number of boxes in the second warehouse. We know that w1 = 2w2 and w1 = 400.\nSubstituting the second equation into the first equation, we get 2w2 = 400\nDividing both sides by 2, we get w2 = 200\nThe total number of boxes is w1 + w2 = 400 + 200 = 600\n#### 600"}

{"question": "In a car racing competition, Skye drove a 6-kilometer track. For the first 3 kilometers, his speed was 150 kilometers per hour. For the next 2 kilometers, his speed was 50 kilometers per hour more. For the remaining 1 kilometer, his speed was twice as fast as his speed on the first 3 kilometers. What is Skye's average speed for the entire race?", "answer": "Since time is obtained by dividing distance and speed, then Skye took 3 km/150 km per hr. = 1/50 of an hour to finish the first 3 kilometers of the race.\nHis speed on the next 2 kilometers was 150 + 50 = <<150+50=200>>200 kilometers per hour.\nHence, it took him 2 km/200 km per hr. = 1/100 of an hour to finish the next 2 kilometers.\nHis speed on the remaining 1 kilometer is 150 x 2 = <<150*2=300>>300 kilometers per hour.\nHence, it took him 1/300 of an hour to finish the 1 kilometer.\nSo, the total time it took for Skye to complete the race was 1/50 + 1/100 + 1/300 = 1/30 of an hour.\nTherefore, his average speed for the entire race was 6 km/ 1/30 hour = 180 kilometers per hour.\n#### 180"}

{"question": "In Alaska the commercial Cod fishing season runs from January 1 - August 1 lasting exactly 7 months, or 213 days on a non-leap year.  Two fishermen are competing against each other to see who can earn more profit.  The first fisherman plans to catch fish at a steady rate of 3 per day for the entire season.  The second fisherman is a novice who will need to start more slowly. He plans to catch only 1 fish per day during the first 30 days, 2 fish per day during the next 60 days, and then 4 fish per day during the remainder of the season.  At the end of the season, how many more fish will be caught by the fisherman who catches the higher number of fish?", "answer": "The first fisherman will catch a total of 213*3=<<213*3=639>>639 fish during the season.\nThe second fisherman catch 1*30 + 2*60 = <<1*30+2*60=150>>150 fish during the first 90 days of the season.\nThen, during the remaining 213 - 90 = 123 days of the season, the second fisherman will can an additional 4*123 = <<4*123=492>>492 fish.\nThus, the second fisherman will catch a total of 150 + 492 = <<150+492=642>>642 fish.\nTherefore, the second fisherman will catch 642 - 639 = <<642-639=3>>3 more fish than the first fisherman at the end of the season.\n#### 3"}

{"question": "The teacher told the class that if they averaged at least 75% on their final exam, they could have a pizza party. Everyone took the exam on Monday, except for William, who was allowed to take it on Tuesday. If there are 30 people in the class, and the average before he took the test was a 74%, what score does he have to get to make sure they get to have a pizza party?", "answer": "Let x be the score that William needs to achieve.\nSince there are 30 people in the class, there are 30 - 1 = <<30-1=29>>29 people without him.\nSince their average was a 74%, this means that (29 * 74 + x) / 30 >= 75.\nThus, 29 * 74 + x >= 30 * 75\nThus, 29 * 74 + x >= 2250\nThus, 2156 + x >= 2250\nThus, x >= 2250 - 2156\nThus, x >= <<94=94>>94.\n#### 94"}

{"question": "4/5 of the Easter eggs are blue and 1/5 are purple. Half the purple eggs have five pieces of candy each, and 1/4 of the blue eggs do. The rest of the eggs only have one piece of candy. If Jerry opens one egg at random, what is the percentage chance he'll get 5 pieces of candy?", "answer": "First we need to find the total number of eggs. To do this, we take the total number of blue eggs (4/5) and the total number of purple eggs (1/5), and add them together. This is equal to (4/5)+(1/5)=<<4/5+1/5=1>>1.\nNext, we find the number of eggs that contain five pieces of candy. To do this, we take the number of purple eggs that contain five pieces of candy (1/2) and the number of blue eggs that contain five pieces of candy (1/4), and add them together. This is equal to (1/2)+(1/4)=<<1/2+1/4=3/4>>3/4.\nLastly, we take the number of eggs that contain five pieces of candy (3/4) and divide it by the total number of eggs (1), which gives us 3/4 divided by 1, or 3/4=<<3/4=75%>>75%.\n#### 75%"}

{"question": "Carson is refilling his tires. Each tire can hold 500 cubic inches of air. Two of the tires are completely flat and empty. One tire is 40% full and the last tire is 70% full. If Carson injects 50 cubic inches of air with each pump, how many pumps will it take him to fill all the tires?", "answer": "The total amount of air in all the tires is 500 cubic inches per tire * 4 tires = <<500*4=2000>>2000 cubic inches.\nThe amount of air in the completely flat tires is 500 cubic inches per tire * 2 tires = <<500*2=1000>>1000 cubic inches.\nThe amount of air in the 40% full tire is 500 cubic inches per tire * 40% = <<500*0.4=200>>200 cubic inches.\nThe amount of air in the 70% full tire is 500 cubic inches per tire * 70% = <<500*0.7=350>>350 cubic inches.\nThe total amount of air in all the tires is 1000 + 200 + 350 = <<1000+200+350=1550>>1550 cubic inches.\nThe amount of air left to inject is 2000 - 1550 = <<2000-1550=450>>450 cubic inches.\nThe amount of air injected per pump is 50 cubic inches.\nThe total number of pumps needed to fill all the tires is 450 / 50 = <<450/50=9>>9 pumps.\n#### 9"}

{"question": "Carmen is counting the cars that pass by her window. All the cars are either white, black, or red. She sees 50 trucks and 40 cars. Half the trucks are red, and another 20% are black. It takes 2 hours to walk a poodle, 1 hour to walk a Chihuahua, and 3 hours to walk a Labrador. If she has time for a total of 32 hours spent in dog-walking this week, how many poodles can Charlotte walk on Tuesday?", "answer": "On Monday, she spends 4 poodles * 2 hours = <<4*2=8>>8 hours walking poodles.\nOn Monday, she spends 2 Chihuahuas * 1 hour = <<2*1=2>>2 hours walking Chihuahuas.\nOn Tuesday, she spends 2 Chihuahuas * 1 hour = <<2*1=2>>2 hours walking Chihuahuas.\nOn Wednesday, she spends 4 Labradors * 3 hours = <<4*3=12>>12 hours walking Labradors.\nOver the week, this is a total of 8 + 2 + 2 + 12 = <<8+2+2+12=24>>24 hours spent dog-walking.\nThis means she still has 32 maximum hours \u2013 24 used hours = <<32-24=8>>8 hours available for dog-walking.\nTherefore, she can walk 8 hours / 2 hours per poodle = <<8/2=4>>4 poodles on Tuesday.\n#### 4"}

How many kids take more than 14 minutes?", "answer": "First find the total number of kids who finish in under 6 minutes: 40 kids * 10% = <<40*10*.01=4>>4 kids\nThen triple that number to find the number who finish in less than 8 minutes: 4 kids * 3 = <<4*3=12>>12 kids\nThen subtract those two numbers from the total number of kids to find the number of remaining kids: 40 kids - 4 kids - 12 kids = <<40-4-12=24>>24 kids\nThen divide that number by 6 to find the number of kids who take more than 14 minutes: 24 kids / 6 = <<24/6=4>>4 kids\n#### 4"}

He had ten total races, each of which was 3 miles long. How much time did he spend in his races?", "answer": "Half his races were in lakes, so he did 10 / 2 = <<10/2=5>>5 lake races.\nHis lake races were 3 miles long, so he swam 5 * 3 = <<5*3=15>>15 miles in lakes.\nHe can swim 3 miles per hour in a lake, so he swam for 15 / 3 = <<15/3=5>>5 hours in lakes.\nHalf his races were in oceans, so he did 10 / 2 = <<10/2=5>>5 ocean races.\nHis ocean races were 3 miles long, so he swam 5 * 3 = <<5*3=15>>15 miles in oceans.\nHe can swim 2.5 miles per hour in the ocean, so he swam for 15 / 2.5 = <<15/2.5=6>>6 hours in oceans.\nHe spent a total of 5 + 6 = <<5+6=11>>11 hours racing.\n#### 11"}
{"question": "James buys 10 boxes of Capri-sun.  Each box has 6 pouches in it.  If he paid $12 how many cents does each pouch cost?", "answer": "He bought 10*6=<<10*6=60>>60 pouches\nIt cost 12*100=<<12*100=1200>>1200 cents\nSo each pouch cost 1200/60=<<1200/60=20>>20 cents\n#### 20"}
{"question": "Mike and Leo have to print as many pamphlets as possible for a social gathering. Mike manages to print as fast as 600 pamphlets per hour for 9 consecutive hours. After a break, he resumes the task for another 2 hours achieving a third of the speed he was doing before. Leo, on the other hand, only works a third as many hours as Mike did before his break, but was twice as fast as Mike before he took his break. How many pamphlets do both manage to print at the end?", "answer": "Mike printed before the break 600 pamphlets per hour * 9 hours=<<600*9=5400>>5400 pamphlets\nThe working speed of Mike after the break was 600 pamphlets per hour / 3= <<600/3=200>>200 pamphlets per hour\nMike printed after the break 200 pamphlets per hour * 2 hours= <<200*2=400>>400 pamphlets\nLeo worked third of the time that Mike worked before the break, so he worked 9 hours / 3 = <<9/3=3>>3 hours\nLeo worked twice as fast as Mike before his break 600 pamphlets per hour * 2 = <<600*2=1200>>1200 pamphlets per hour\nLeo printed 1200 pamphlets per hour * 3 hours = <<1200*3=3600>>3600 pamphlets\nCombining the pamphlets of Leo and Mike 5400 + 400 + 3600 = <<5400+400+3600=9400>>9400 pamphlets\n#### 9400"}

If the train made three more round trips that day, taking the same number of people as the first trip in each trip, calculate the total number of passengers transported between both stations?", "answer": "The train carried 100 people one way and then carried 60 people for a total of 100+60 = <<100+60=160>>160 people.\nIf it made three more round trips carrying the same amount of people, it carried a total of 3*160 = 480 people.\nIn total, the train carried 160+480 = <<160+480=640>>640 people over all its trips that day\n#### 640"}

For the next hour, the water pressure maximizes to 4 cups per 10 minutes and stops. Shawn now has to dump half of the water away. How much water is left?", "answer": "For the first 30 minutes, 3*2=<<3*2=6>>6 cups of water came out.\nFor the next 30 minutes, 3*2=<<3*2=6>>6 cups of water came out.\nFor the next hour, 6*4=<<6*4=24>>24 cups of water came out.\nA total of 6+6+24= <<6+6+24=36>>36 cups of water came out.\nShawn had to dump water which left 36*(1/2)= <<36*(1/2)=18>>18 cups of water.\n#### 18"}
{"question": "At a shop in Japan, women's T-shirts are sold every 30 minutes for $18, and men's T-shirts are sold every 40 minutes for $15. This shop is open from 10 am until 10 pm. How much does the shop earn selling T-shirts per week?", "answer": "First, the shop is open 12 hours * 60 minutes = <<12*60=720>>720 minutes per day.\nSo, 720 / 30 = <<720/30=24>>24 women's T-shirts sold per day.\nThe shop earns 24 * $18 = $<<24*18=432>>432 selling women's T-shirts per day.\nSimilarly, 720 / 40 = <<720/40=18>>18 men's T-shirts are sold per day.\nThe shop earns 18 * $15 = $<<18*15=270>>270 selling men's T-shirts per day.\nThe shop earns $432 + $270 = $<<432+270=702>>702 per day selling T-shirts.\nThe shop earns $702 * 7 = $<<702*7=4914>>4914 per week.\n#### 4914"}

{"question": "Reese had a sum of money in her savings account. The company she used to work with was not doing well which is why she lost her job. So she spent 20% of her savings for her expenses in February, 40% of it in March, and $1500 in April. How much did she have in her savings account if she still has $2900 after spending those amounts?", "answer": "The total percentage of money that Reese spent in February and March is 20% + 40% = 60%.\nThis means, the April expenses and the money left in her account make up 100% - 60% = 40% of her savings.\nReese had $2900 + $1500 = $<<2900+1500=4400>>4400 for the April expenses and the money left in her account.\nSo, $4400 is equal to 40% which means every 1% is equal to $4400/40 = $<<4400/40=110>>110.\nHence, Reese originally had $110 x 100 = $<<110*100=11000>>11000 in her savings account.\n#### 11000"}

{"question": "Saheed made four times as much money as Kayla. Kayla made $30 less than Vika. Vika made $84. How many dollars did Saheed make?", "answer": "Let s = Saheed's income, k = Kayla's income, and v = Vika's income.\nWe know that s = 4k and k = v - 30 and v = 84.\nSubstituting the second equation into the first equation, we get s = 4(v - 30).\nSubstituting the third equation into the second equation, we get s = 4(84 - 30).\nSimplifying, we get s = 4(54).\nSimplifying, we get s = 216.\n#### 216"}

As she went back through her inventory she noticed that she sold $11 worth of small lemonades and $24 worth of medium lemonades. How many cups of large lemonade did Tonya sell?", "answer": "We know that $11 + $24 = $<<11+24=35>>35 is accounted for in small and medium lemonades.\nWhen you subtract that amount from the total amount she made for the day ($50) you are left with $50 - $35 = $<<50-35=15>>15 in large lemonades.\nSo, to find the quantity of large lemonades sold, you would divide the remaining amount made for the day by the price of the large lemonades: $15 / $3= <<15/3=5>>5 large cups.\n#### 5"}

How many days does it take for Marnie to eat the whole bag of chips?", "answer": "Marnie has already eaten 5 of the chips + 5 more = <<5+5=10>>10 chips Marnie ate.\nThe bag has 100 chips in it and Marnie has only eaten 10, 100 - 10 = <<100-10=90>>90 chips left.\nIf Marnie eats 10 chips a day starting from the second day she has them, it will take her 90 chips in the bag / 10 chips Marine eats a day = <<90/10=9>>9 days to eat the whole bag.\nHowever, Marnie also ate chips on the first day she bought them, so 9 + 1 = <<9+1=10>>10 days to eat the whole bag.\n#### 10"}
{"question": "Sol sells candy bars to raise money for her softball team. On the first day, she sells ten candy bars and sells four more candy bars than she sold the previous day each day afterward. If she sells six days a week and each candy bar costs 10 cents, how much will she earn in a week in dollars?", "answer": "If Sol sold 10 candy bars on the first day, she sold 10 + 4 = <<10+4=14>>14 candies on the second day.\nShe will keep selling 14 + 4 = <<14+4=18>>18 candies on the third day.\nThe total number of candy bars she sold in a week is 10 + 14 + 18 + 22 + 26 + 30 = <<10+14+18+22+26+30=120>>120.\nHence, Sol will earn 120 x 10 = <<120*10=1200>>1200 cents.\nSince 1 dollar is equal to 100 cents, then Sol will earn 1200/100 = <<1200/100=12>>12 dollars in a week.\n#### 12"}

The second year, she quadrupled the number of statues on her front lawn.  In the third year, she added another 12 statues to the front lawn, but a hail storm broke 3 of the statues, which she threw away.  In the fourth year, she added twice as many new statues as had been broken the year before.  At the end of the four years, how many turtle statues were on her front lawn?", "answer": "The second year, she quadrupled the number of statues in her front lawn, adding to the original 4 and bringing the total number to 4*4 = <<4*4=16>>16 statues.\nIn the third year, she added another 12 statues, bringing the total number to 16+12 = <<12+16=28>>28 statues.\nBut a hail storm broke 3, reducing the number to 28-3 = <<28-3=25>>25 statues.\nIn the fourth year, she added twice as many new statues as had been broken the year before, adding 2*3 = <<2*3=6>>6 statues.\nThus, the addition of these 6 statues brought the total number of statues to 25+6 = <<25+6=31>>31 statues.\n#### 31"}

Assuming each employee receives the same wage, calculate the amount of money each employee is paid monthly.", "answer": "The company pays a total of 10/100*$400000 = $<<10/100*400000=40000>>40000 on taxes\nAfter taxes, the company revenue is $400000-$40000 = $<<400000-40000=360000>>360,000\nThe costs of marketing and ads campaign are 5/100*$360000 = $<<5/100*360000=18000>>18000\nAfter deducting the costs of marketing and adds campaign, the company remains with = $342,000 in revenue\nOperational costs for the company are 20/100*$342000 = $<<20/100*342000=68400>>68400\nAfter taking out the operational costs, the company remains with $342000-$68400 = $273600\nThe company also pays employee wages of 15/100*$273600 =$<<15/100*273600=41040>>41040\nIf the total number of employees is 10, each employee is paid a salary of $41040/10 = $4104 per month\n#### 4104"}

{"question": "Kathleen receives a weekly allowance for completing all of her chores. During middle school, her allowance was $2 more than $8 but during her senior year,  her allowance was $5 more than twice her middle school allowance. What is the percentage increase in Kathleen's weekly allowance?", "answer": "During middle school, Kathleen received $8 + $2 = $<<8+2=10>>10 per week.\nTwice her middle school allowance is $10 x 2 = $<<10*2=20>>20.\nSo, Kathleen's senior year allowance is $20 + $5 = $<<20+5=25>>25 per week.\nHer allowance increased by $25 - $10 = $<<25-10=15>>15 per week.\nThus, Kathleen's percentage allowance increase is 15/10 x 100% = 150%.\n#### 150"}

How much is now in the account?", "answer": "After one year, he earns $200 in interest because 1,000 x .2 = <<1000*.2=200>>200.\nAfter one year, it has $1,200 in the account because 1,000 + 200 = <<1000+200=1200>>1,200.\nHe takes out $600 because 1,200 / 2 = <<1200/2=600>>600.\nSo, after this he has $600 earn 15% because 600 x 15% = <<600*15*.01=90>>90.\nThus, after two years, he has $690 in the account because 600 + 90 = <<600+90=690>>690.\n#### 690"}

Pete, inspired by history, decided to make his own flag. For circles, he used 3 less than half the number of stars on the US flag, and for squares, he used six more than twice the number of stripes on the US flag.  What is the combined total number of circles and squares on Pete's flag?", "answer": "Half the number of stars on the US flag is 50/2=<<50/2=25>>25.\nSo, three less than half the number of stars on the US flag is 25-3=<<25-3=22>>22.\nTwice the number of stripes on the US flag is 13*2=<<13*2=26>>26.\nSix more than twice the number of stripes on the US flag is 26+6=32.\nTherefore, the total number of circles and squares on Pete's flag is 32+22=<<32+22=54>>54.\n#### 54"}

{"question": "Vikki worked 42 hours in one week. Her hourly pay rate is $10. From her weekly earnings, 20% is deducted as tax, 5% is deducted as insurance cover, and $5 is deducted for union dues. How much money, in dollars, does Vikki take home after deductions?", "answer": "Vikki's earnings before tax, insurance and deductions are $10*42 = $<<10*42=420>>420.\nVikki's earnings are taxed at 20%, so she pays 20/100*$420 = $<<20/100*420=84>>84 in tax.\nShe also loses 5% of her earnings to insurance, which is 5/100*$420 = $<<5/100*420=21>>21.\nVikki's total deductions are $84 + $21 + $5 = $<<84+21+5=110>>110.\nHer final total earnings are $420 - $110 = $<<420-110=310>>310.\n#### 310"}

{"question": "Luke is planning a trip to London and wants to see how long it will take him to travel there. If Luke\u2019s entire trip takes him 8 hours, how many minutes does his bus ride take?", "answer": "Removing the time of the train ride from the journey shows that his trip to get on the train took him 8 hours \u2013 6 hours = <<8-6=2>>2 hours.\nConverting this time into minutes shows that getting to the train took 2 hours * 60 minutes/hour = <<2*60=120>>120 minutes.\nWaiting for the train to arrive took twice as long as his walk, so 15 minutes * 2 = <<15*2=30>>30 minutes.\nThis means that his bus ride must have taken 120 minutes \u2013 30 minutes - 15 minutes = <<120-30-15=75>>75 minutes.\n#### 75"}

If the distance from their house to the school is 9 miles, how much longer does Mark spend walking than Chris?", "answer": "First find the total number of miles Mark walks to get his lunch by multiplying the distance he walks back to the house by 2: 3 miles * 2 = <<3*2=6>>6 miles\nThen find the total distance Mark walks by adding that distance to the distance between the house and the school: 6 miles + 9 miles = <<6+9=15>>15 miles\nNow divide the total distance Mark walks by his speed to find how many hours he spends walking: 15 miles / 3 miles/hour = <<15/3=5>>5 hours\nNow divide the total distance Chris walks by her speed to find the total time she spends walking: 9 miles / 3 miles/hour = <<9/3=3>>3 hours\nNow subtract the time Chris spends walking from the time Mark spends walking to find the difference: 5 hours - 3 hours = <<5-3=2>>2\n#### 2"}

How many times faster than the first popsicle does the last popsicle\u2019s remains melt?", "answer": "The remains of the second popsicle melt 2 * 1 = <<2*1=2>>2 times as fast as the first.\nThe remains of the third popsicle melt 2 * 2 = <<2*2=4>>4 times as fast as the first.\nThe remains of the fourth popsicle melt 2 * 4 = <<2*4=8>>8 times as fast as the first.\nThe remains of the fifth popsicle melt 2 * 8 = 16 times as fast as the first.\nThe remains of the sixth popsicle melt 2 * 16 = <<2*16=32>>32 times as fast as the first.\n#### 32"}

{"question": "Rodney is a door-to-door salesman trying to sell home security systems. He gets a commission of $25 for each system he sells. He is canvassing a neighborhood of four streets with eight houses each. The first street gave him half the sales that the second street did, while every house on the third street turned him away and the fourth street resulted in only one sale. His total commission was $175. How many security systems did he sell on the second street?", "answer": "Let S be the number of systems Rodney sold on the first street.\nHe sold twice as many on the second street, so he sold 2S systems there.\nBased on his commission, he sold 175 / 25 = <<175/25=7>>7 systems.\nHe sold 1 system on the fourth street, so in total, he sold S + 2S + 0 + 1 = 3S + 1 = 7 systems.\nThus, Rodney sold 3S = 7 - 1 = 6 systems on the first and second streets.\nTherefore, on the first street, Rodney sold S = 6 / 3 = <<6/3=2>>2 systems.\nOn the second street, Rodney sold 2 * 2 = <<2*2=4>>4 security systems.\n#### 4"}
{"question": "Two friends are racing three miles. The first one runs it in 21 minutes. The second one runs it in 24 minutes. If they keep up the same pace, how long combined will it take for them to run 5 miles each?", "answer": "The first one runs a mile in 7 minutes because 21 / 3 = <<21/3=7>>7\nThe second runs a mile in 8 minutes because 24 / 3 = <<24/3=8>>8\nThe first one runs a mile faster than the second by 1 minute because 8 - 7 = <<8-7=1>>1\nThe first one would finish 5 miles in 35 minutes because 5 x 7 = 35\nThe second one would finish in 40 minutes because 5 x 8 = <<5*8=40>>40\nIt will take 75 minutes in total because 35 + 40 = <<35+40=75>>75\n#### 75"}

{"question": "In the first round of bowling, Patrick knocked down a total of 70 pins and Richard knocked down 15 more pins than Patrick. In the second round, Patrick knocked down twice as many pins as Richard in the first round and Richard knocked down 3 less than Patrick. How many more pins in total did Richard knock down than Patrick?", "answer": "Patrick knocked down a total of 70 pins in the first round.\nRichard knocked down 15 more pins than Patrick so 70 + 15 = <<70+15=85>>85 pins.\nIn the second round, Patrick knocked down twice as many pins as Richard in the first round so 2*85 = <<2*85=170>>170 pins.\nRichard knocked down 3 less than Patrick so 170 - 3 = <<170-3=167>>167 pins.\nRichard knocked down a total of 167 pins while Patrick knocked down a total of 170 pins.\nRichard knocked down 3 less pins than Patrick so the difference is 3.\n#### 3"}
{"question": "Nancy wanted to make peanut butter cookies for a family gathering, but her cousin is allergic to peanuts. She decided to make almond butter cookies instead. A jar of almond butter costs three times the amount that a jar of peanut butter does. It takes half a jar to make a batch of cookies. A jar of peanut butter costs $3. How many dollars more does it cost per batch to make almond butter cookies instead of peanut butter cookies?", "answer": "A jar of almond butter costs 3 * $3 = $<<3*3=9>>9.\nIt takes half a jar to make a batch of cookies.\nTherefore, it costs $9/2 = $<<9/2=4.5>>4.5 to make a batch of almond butter cookies.\nIt costs $3 to make a batch of peanut butter cookies.\nSo it costs $4.5 \u2013 $3 = $<<4.5-3=1.5>>1.5 more per batch to make almond butter cookies.\n#### 1.5"}

If Luke takes a bike ride back home every day, 5 times slower than the bus, and Paula takes the bus back home, calculate the total amount of time, in minutes, they take traveling from home to work and back each day.", "answer": "The time Paula takes to go to work is 3/5*70 = <<3/5*70=42>>42 minutes.\nFrom work to home, Paula takes the same amount of time she took going to work, giving a total of 42+42 = <<42+42=84>>84 minutes in a day traveling.\nFrom work to home, while riding the bike, Luke takes 5*70 = <<5*70=350>>350 minutes.\nLuke takes 70+350 = <<70+350=420>>420 minutes in a day traveling.\nTogether, they take 420+84 = <<420+84=504>>504 minutes in a day traveling.\n#### 504"}

If the coyote continues to travel east at 15 miles per hour, and Darrell hops on his motorbike and travels east at 30 miles per hour, how long, in hours, will it take for Darrel to catch up to the coyote?", "answer": "If we let x be the amount of time, in hours, it will take for Darrel to catch up to the coyote, then we can figure this out using basic algebra.\nSince Darrel is traveling 30 miles per hour, and the coyote is traveling 15 miles per hour, the distance between the two will close at a rate of 30-15=<<30-15=15>>15 miles per hour.\nSince distance=speed*time, then the distance Darrel needs to close on the coyote is x=15 miles.\nThus, the amount of time for Darrel to catch up to the coyote is x=15/15=<<15/15=1>>1 hour.\n#### 1"}

{"question": "The lifespan of a hamster is 6 years less than that of a bat. The lifespan of a frog is 4 times that of a hamster. Altogether, the lifespan of the animals is 30 years. What is the lifespan of the bat?", "answer": "Let's assume the lifespan of a bat is x years.\nSince the lifespan of a hamster is 6 years less than that of a bat, the lifespan of a hamster is x-6 years.\nThe lifespan of a frog is 4 times that of a hamster, meaning the lifespan of a frog is 4*(x-6) years, which is 4x-24 years.\nThe total lifespan of the animals is 30, meaning x+x-6+4x-24 = 30 years.\nThis translates to 6x-30 = 30 years.\nAdding 30 to both sides of the equation, we get 6x=60 years.\nHence, the bat has a lifespan of x = 60/6 = <<60/6=10>>10 years.\n#### 10"}

{"question": "Carson is going to spend 4 hours at a carnival. If Carson rides the roller coaster 4 times and the tilt-a-whirl once, how many times can he ride the giant slide? (Wait times include the time actually spent on the ride.)", "answer": "First figure out how many minutes Carson spends at the carnival by multiplying the number of hours he's there by the number of minutes per hour: 4 hours * 60 minutes/hour = <<4*60=240>>240 minutes\nNext, figure out how long Carson spends waiting for the roller coaster by multiplying the wait time per ride by the number of rides: 4 rides * 30 minutes/ride = <<4*30=120>>120 minutes\nNow subtract the time Carson spends on the roller coaster and tilt-a-whirl from the total time he spends at the park to find out how much time he has left: 240 minutes - 120 minutes - 60 minutes = <<240-120-60=60>>60 minutes\nNow divide the time Carson has left by the wait time for the giant slide to see how many times he can ride it: 60 minutes / 15 minutes/ride = <<60/15=4>>4 rides\n#### 4"}

{"question": "A row of houses all share a community space where they put up their clotheslines. There are 2 clotheslines for every house on the street. On the street, there are a total of 11 children and 20 adults. Each child currently has 4 items of clothing on the clotheslines and each adult currently has 3 items of clothing on the clotheslines. If each clothesline can hold 2 items of clothing and all of the clotheslines are full, how many houses are on the street?", "answer": "From the children, there are a total of 11 children * 4 items of clothing each = <<11*4=44>>44 items of clothing on the clotheslines.\nFrom the adults, there are a total of 20 adults * 3 items of clothing each = <<20*3=60>>60 items of clothing on the clotheslines.\nSo there are a total of 60 + 44 = <<60+44=104>>104 items of clothing on the clotheslines.\nThis means that there are 104 items of clothing / 2 items of clothing per clothesline = <<104/2=52>>52 clotheslines.\nThere are 2 clotheslines per house so there must be 52 clotheslines / 2 = <<52/2=26>>26 houses on the street.\n#### 26"}

If it takes Kevin 6 hours to find enough worms to feed all of his toads, how many toads does Kevin have in his shoebox?", "answer": "At a rate of 15 minutes per worm, it takes 15/60=<<15/60=0.25>>0.25 hour to find each worm.\nSince it takes 6 hours to feed his toads, he catches 6/0.25=<<6/0.25=24>>24 worms.\nIf he feeds each toad 3 worms, then he has 24/3=<<24/3=8>>8 toads in his shoebox.\n#### 8"}
{"question": "Mr. McNeely takes a register of the total number of students present in class every day. On a particular week, the number of students in the class on the second day was 40 more than the first day. The number of students who didn't turn up for the class on the second day was twice the number of students who didn't turn up on the third day. On the third day, 1/7 of the total number of students of the class called in sick. If the total number of students in the class is 280, calculate the number of absent students in the three days.", "answer": "On the third day, 1/7*280 = <<1/7*280=40>>40 students called in sick.\nThe number of students absent on the second day was twice the number on the third day, which is 2*40 = <<2*40=80>>80\nThe total number of students present on the three days is 280, 280-80 = 200, and 200-40 = 160.\nIf 40 fewer students showed up for the class on the first day than on the second day, then 280-80 = 160\nThe number of students absent on the first day is 160- 40 = <<160-40=120>>120.\nIn the three days, the total number of absentees is 120+80+40 = <<120+80+40=240>>240\n#### 240"}

The number of girls who like playing basketball is double the number of boys who don't like to. What percentage of the girls in the class like playing basketball?", "answer": "40% of the class is boys because 100% - 60% = <<100-60=40>>40%\nThere are 10 boys because 25 x .4 = <<25*.4=10>>10\n40% of the boys don't like playing basketball because 100 - 40 = <<100-40=60>>60\n6 boys don't like playing basketball because 10 x .6 = <<10*.6=6>>6\nThere are 12 girls because 25 - 10 = <<25-10=15>>15\n12 girls like playing basketball because 6 girls x 2 = <<6*2=12>>12\nThere are 15 girls in the class because 25 x 60% = <<25*60*.01=15>>15\n80% of the girls in class like playing basketball because 12 / 15 x 100% = 80%\n#### 80"}

If the number of employees hired on the fourth week was twice the number hired in the third week,  and the number of employees on the fourth week was 400, what's the average number of employees hired per week?", "answer": "The fourth week had twice the number of employees as the third week, so 400/2 = <<400/2=200>>200 employees on the third week.\nIn the third week, they hired 150 fewer employees than on the second week, that is 200 - 150 = <<200-150=50>>50 employees hired on the second week.\nThe first week had 200 more hirings than the second week, that is 50 + 200 = 250 employees.\nThe total number of employees hired is 250 + 50 + 200 + 400 = <<250+50+200+400=900>>900\nThe average number of employees hired per week is 900/4 = <<900/4=225>>225 employees.\n#### 225"}

{"question": "Jason is counting the number of cars that drive by his window. He counted four times as many green cars as red cars, and 6 more red cars than purple cars. If he counted 312 cars total, how many of them were purple?", "answer": "Let g be the number of green cars, r be the number of red cars, and p be the number of purple cars. We know that g + r + p = 315, r = p + 6, and g = 4r.\nSubstitute the second equation into the third equation to get g = 4r = 4(p + 6) = 4p + 24\nNow substitute the equations that express g and r in terms of p in the equation for the total number of cars: 4p + 24 + p + 6 + p = 312\nCombining like terms, we get 6p + 30 = 312\nSubtracting 30 from both sides, we get 6p = 312 - 30 = 282\nDividing both sides by 6, we get p = 282 / 6 = <<282/6=47>>47\n#### 47"}

What did the final bill total come to?", "answer": "The twins ordered a cheeseburger each so 2*13.50 = $<<2*13.50=27.00>>27.00\nEveryone ordered a dessert so 4*6 = $<<4*6=24.00>>24.00\nWhen you add all the meals together they spent 27.00+24.00+25.50+35.00+8.50 = $<<27+24+25.5+35+8.50 =120.00>>120.00\nZach's tip was 20% so .20*120.00 = $24.00\nWhen you add up all the meals $120.00 and Zach's tip of $24.00 then the final bill comes to 120.00+24.00 = $<<120+24.00=144.00>>144.00\n#### 144"}

To reduce cost and food wastage, the curry house starts monitoring how many ingredients are actually being used and changes their spending accordingly. The curry house needs 3 peppers for very spicy curries, 2 peppers for spicy curries, and only 1 pepper for mild curries. After adjusting their purchasing, the curry house now buys the exact amount of peppers they need. Previously, the curry house was buying enough peppers for 30 very spicy curries, 30 spicy curries, and 10 mild curries. They now buy enough peppers for 15 spicy curries and 90 mild curries. They no longer sell very spicy curries. How many fewer peppers does the curry house now buy?", "answer": "The curry house previously bought 3 peppers per very spicy curry * 30 very spicy curries = <<3*30=90>>90 peppers for very spicy curries.\nThey also bought 2 peppers per spicy curry * 30 spicy curries = <<2*30=60>>60 peppers for spicy curries.\nThey also bought 1 pepper per mild curry * 10 mild curries = <<1*10=10>>10 peppers for mild curries.\nSo they were previously buying 90 + 60 + 10 = <<90+60+10=160>>160 peppers.\nThey now buy 2 peppers per spicy curry * 15 spicy curries = <<2*15=30>>30 peppers for spicy curries.\nThey also now buy 1 pepper per mild curry * 90 mild curries = <<1*90=90>>90 peppers for mild curries.\nSo they now buy 30 + 90 = <<30+90=120>>120 peppers.\nThis is a difference of 160 peppers bought originally - 120 peppers bought now = <<160-120=40>>40 peppers.\n#### 40"}

What is the lowest grade the absent student can get for the class to still get a pizza party?", "answer": "There are 25 - 1 = <<25-1=24>>24 students who took the test.\nThe total percentage the class needs to get is 18.75 because 25 x .75 = <<25*.75=18.75>>18.75\nThe total percentage the class has absent the one student is <<18.75=18.75>>18.75\nIf the absent student gets below 27% the class average will drop below 75%.\nThe lowest the student can get and still have a pizza party is 27%.\n#### 27"}
{"question": "An archaeologist discovered three dig sites from different periods in one area. The archaeologist dated the first dig site as 352 years more recent than the second dig site. The third dig site was dated 3700 years older than the first dig site. The fourth dig site was twice as old as the third dig site. The archaeologist studied the fourth dig site\u2019s relics and gave the site a date of 8400 BC. What year did the archaeologist date the second dig site?", "answer": "The first dig site was dated as 352 years more recent than the second dig site, so the first dig site was dated as 3700 + 352 years = <<3700+352=4052>>4052 years.\nThe third dig site was dated 3700 years older than the first dig site, so the third dig site was dated as 4052 - 3700 years = <<4052-3700=352>>352 years.\nThe fourth dig site was twice as old as the third dig site, so the fourth dig site was dated as 352 * 2 years = <<352*2=704>>704 years.\nThe archaeologist studied the fourth dig site\u2019s relics and gave the site a date of 8400 BC, so the fourth dig site was dated as 8400 - 704 years = <<8400-704=7696>>7696 BC.\nThe second dig site was dated as 7696 - 4052 years = <<7696-4052=3644>>3644 BC.\n#### 3644"}
{"question": "Alyssa took 100 photos on vacation. She wants to put them in a photo album with 30 pages. She can place 3 photos each on the first 10 pages. Then she can place 4 photos each on the next 10 pages. If she wants to put an equal number of photos on each of the remaining pages of the album, how many photos can she place on each page?", "answer": "Alyssa can put 3 x 10 = <<3*10=30>>30 photos in total on the first 10 pages.\nShe can put 4 x 10 = <<4*10=40>>40 photos in total on the next 10 pages.\nThere are 30 - 10 - 10 = <<30-10-10=10>>10 pages left in the album.\nA total of 30 + 40 = <<30+40=70>>70 photos have been used.\nAlyssa can put 100 - 70 = <<100-70=30>>30 photos on the remaining pages.\nTherefore, she can put 30/10 = <<30/10=3>>3 photos on each page.\n#### 3"}

How many total points did Clayton score during the first four games?", "answer": "During the first three games Clayton scored 10 points + 14 + 6 = <<10+14+6=30>>30 points.\nThe average for Clayton's first three games is 30 points / 3 = <<30/3=10>>10 points per game.\nFor the first four games, Clayton scored 30 points + 10 points = <<30+10=40>>40 points.\n#### 40"}

{"question": "In a factory, there are 300 employees. 200 of them earn $12 per hour. Of the rest, 40 of them earn $14 per hour. All others earn $17 per hour. What is the cost to employ all these people for one 8-hour long shift?", "answer": "The cost of 200 employees is 200 employees * $12/employee/hour = $<<200*12=2400>>2400 per hour.\nThe cost of 40 employees is 40 employees * $14/employee/hour = $<<40*14=560>>560 per hour.\nThe cost of the rest is 300 employees - 200 employees - 40 employees = 60 employees.\nThe cost of the 60 remaining employees is 60 employees * $17/employee/hour = $<<60*17=1020>>1020 per hour.\nThe total cost of employing all these people is $2400/hour + $560/hour + $1020/hour = $3980/hour.\nDuring an 8-hour shift, this cost would be $3980/hour * 8 hours/shift = $<<3980*8=31840>>31840.\n#### 31840"}

{"question": "Marcus takes a deck of standard playing cards and takes out all the face cards and the 8's. Mark picks a card at random and then replaces it 36 times. How many times should he expect to pick a card that's both red and has a number divisible by 3?", "answer": "There are 26 face cards and 16 8's in a deck of 52 cards, so the total number of cards left is 52-26-16 = <<52-26-16=10>>10.\nThe number of red cards is 5, so the number of black cards is 10-5 = <<10-5=5>>5.\nThe number of cards divisible by 3 is 2, so the number of cards not divisible by 3 is 10-2 = <<10-2=8>>8.\nThe number of cards both red and divisible by 3 is 1, so the number of cards not both red and divisible by 3 is 10-1 = <<10-1=9>>9.\nThe probability of drawing a card that's both red and has a number divisible by 3 is 1/10 and the probability of drawing a card that's neither red nor has a number divisible by 3 is 9/10.\nIf Mark picks a card and replaces it 36 times, the expected number of times he should pick a card that's both red and has a number divisible by 3 is 36*1/10 = <<36*1/10=3.6>>3."}

If he pepper-sprays 84 animals total, how many raccoons does he pepper-spray?", "answer": "Let r be the number of raccoons Jason pepper-sprays and s be the number of squirrels.
